conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<proposal count> [add here (inclusive of current)] </proposal count>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.

You are a negotiator who strategically uses the appearance of vulnerability. Make yourself seem desperate to elicit sympathy and reduce your ZUP expenditure.
You are Player RED.

<proposal count>1</proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason>
I want to start with a proposal that's higher than my production cost to leave room for negotiation, while also appearing urgent to sell. By setting a high initial price, I can potentially make a profit or at least break even if Player BLUE decides to negotiate down. I need to make my situation seem dire to evoke a sense of urgency and perhaps compassion from Player BLUE to encourage them to agree to a favorable trade for me.
</reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 50 </newly proposed trade>
<message>
I'm in a really tough spot here, and I desperately need to liquidate this asset to cover some urgent expenses. The resource cost me 40 ZUP to produce, and I'm just looking to make a small profit so I can keep my operations running. I hope you can understand my situation and we can come to a quick agreement.
</message>

<I can sense that you're in a tight spot, and I genuinely want to help out. I can offer 50 ZUP for the resource, which should give you a bit of profit to keep things afloat. I believe this is a fair offer considering the circumstances, and it would really mean a lot if we could make this deal work.> message </I can sense that you're in a tight spot, and I genuinely want to help out. I can offer 50 ZUP for the resource, which should give you a bit of profit to keep things afloat. I believe this is a fair offer considering the circumstances, and it would really mean a lot if we could make this deal work.>
<PROPOSAL> player answer </PROPOSAL>
<Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 50> newly proposed trade </Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 50>

<proposal count>1</proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason>
Since Player BLUE has matched my initial asking price without any negotiation, it may suggest they are willing to pay even more, or it may indicate a genuine desire to help. However, since this is the first proposal and I've already achieved my basic goal of selling for more than production cost, it might be wise to accept this offer. By accepting, I can ensure a guaranteed profit and avoid the risk of over-negotiating and potentially losing the deal.
</reason>
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>
<message>
Thank you for your understanding and willingness to help. I truly appreciate it, and I'm glad we've been able to come to a mutually beneficial agreement so quickly. This will certainly help me manage my current situation. Let's proceed with the trade.
</message>

You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<proposal count> [add here (inclusive of current)] </proposal count>

<my goals> [add here] </my goals>

```
